flashcards.back: A collection of ductless glands that secrete hormones into the bloodstream to regulate metabolism, growth, reproduction, and other body functions.

flashcards.front: What is the role of the hypothalamus?
flashcards.back: Acts as the master regulator by producing releasing and inhibiting hormones that control the anterior pituitary gland.

flashcards.front: What hormones are produced by the anterior pituitary gland?
flashcards.back: TSH (Thyroid-Stimulating Hormone), ACTH (Adrenocorticotropic Hormone), GH (Growth Hormone), LH (Luteinizing Hormone), FSH (Follicle-Stimulating Hormone), Prolactin.

flashcards.front: What is the function of TSH (Thyroid-Stimulating Hormone)?
flashcards.back: Stimulates the thyroid gland to produce thyroid hormones (T3 and T4), which regulate metabolism.

flashcards.front: What is the function of ACTH (Adrenocorticotropic Hormone)?
flashcards.back: Stimulates the adrenal cortex to release cortisol and other glucocorticoids.

flashcards.front: What is the function of GH (Growth Hormone)?
flashcards.back: Promotes growth, cell reproduction, and regeneration in tissues, especially bones and muscles.

flashcards.front: What is the function of LH (Luteinizing Hormone) and FSH (Follicle-Stimulating Hormone)?
flashcards.back: LH triggers ovulation and stimulates the production of sex hormones in the ovaries and testes; FSH stimulates the growth of ovarian follicles and sperm production.

flashcards.front: What is the role of prolactin?
flashcards.back: Stimulates milk production in the mammary glands.

flashcards.front: What hormones are stored and released by the posterior pituitary gland?
flashcards.back: ADH (Antidiuretic Hormone) and Oxytocin, both produced by the hypothalamus.
